dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so, have you been keeping an eye on this whole 'buy now, pay later' space? It's like, absolutely blowing up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so, have you been keeping an eye on this whole buy now, pay later space? It's like, absolutely blowing up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally, A. I mean, Afterpay, right? From, uh, a billion in 2018 to eighteen billion now? That's insane growth. And Affirm's doing an IPO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally, A. I mean, Afterpay, right? From, uh, a billion in twenty eighteen to eighteen billion now? That's insane growth. And Affirm's doing an I P O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Australian company Afterpay, whose entire business is staked on the scheme, has sailed from a market valuation of $1 billion in 2018 to $18 billion today. Eight-year-old San Francisco startup Affirm is rumored to be planning an IPO that could fetch $10 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And now PayPal, of all companies, is, uh, cramming into the space with their "Pay in 4" product.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And now PayPal, of all companies, is, uh, cramming into the space with their Pay in four product.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now PayPal PYPL -0.3% is cramming into the space. Its new Pay in 4 product will let you pay for any items that cost between $30 and $600 in four installments over six weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that. So, it's for items between thirty and six hundred bucks, split into four payments over six weeks. But the fees are, like, the big differentiator, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that. So, it's for items between thirty and six hundred bucks, split into four payments over six weeks. But the fees are, like, the big differentiator, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its new Pay in 4 product will let you pay for any items that cost between $30 and $600 in four installments over six weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! Afterpay charges retailers about five percent, no interest for consumers, but late fees if you're, uh, slow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! Afterpay charges retailers about five percent, no interest for consumers, but late fees if you're, uh, slow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Afterpay charges retailers roughly 5% of each transaction to offer its financing feature. It doesnt charge interest to the consumer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] And Affirm, they mostly make users pay interest, sometimes ten to thirty percent, but no late fees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Affirm, they mostly make users pay interest, sometimes ten to thirty percent, but no late fees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Affirm also charges retailers transaction fees. But most of the time, it makes users pay interest of 10 - 30%, and it has no late fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And PayPal, it seems to be this, like, lower-cost hybrid. No interest to consumers, no extra fee to retailers...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And PayPal, it seems to be this, like, lower-cost hybrid. No interest to consumers, no extra fee to retailers...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal seems to be a lower-cost hybrid of the two. It wont charge interest to the consumer or an additional fee to the retailer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay a fee of up to $10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But a small late fee, up to ten bucks. Which, you know, makes sense for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But a small late fee, up to ten bucks. Which, you know, makes sense for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wont charge interest to the consumer or an additional fee to the retailer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay a fee of up to $10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's also wild to think that Max Levchin, the serial entrepreneur, he started both PayPal *and* Affirm. Two of the big players!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's also wild to think that Max Levchin, the serial entrepreneur, he started both PayPal and Affirm. Two of the big players!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Serial entrepreneur Max Levchin started two of the three major players offering online point of sale financing in the U.S. He cofounded PayPal with Peter Thiel in 1999 and started Affirm in 2012.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And PayPal's advantage is huge. They can totally undercut the competition because they already have this, uh, dominant payments network.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And PayPal's advantage is huge. They can totally undercut the competition because they already have this, uh, dominant payments network.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal can undercut the competition on fees because it already has a dominant, highly profitable payments network it can leverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, eighty percent of top retailers, nearly seventy percent of US online buyers already use PayPal. So, they just leverage that existing ecosystem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, eighty percent of top retailers, nearly seventy percent of U S online buyers already use PayPal. So, they just leverage that existing ecosystem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Eighty percent of the top 100 retailers in the U.S. let customers pay with PayPal, and nearly 70% of U.S. online buyers have PayPal accounts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And, get this, data shows consumers spend, like, twenty percent more when these point-of-sale financing options are available.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And, get this, data shows consumers spend, like, twenty percent more when these point-of-sale financing options are available.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Data from Afterpay and PayPal show that consumers spend more moneysometimes 20% morewhen theyre offered point of sale financing options.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So it's a win-win for them â€“ more transactions, more revenue from their existing per-transaction fees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So it's a win-win for them - more transactions, more revenue from their existing per-transaction fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not like their old PayPal Credit, which was high interest and they offloaded the loans. With Pay in 4, they're actually putting it on their own balance sheet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not like their old PayPal Credit, which was high interest and they offloaded the loans. With Pay in four, they're actually putting it on their own balance sheet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Like a credit card, it levies high interest rates of about 25% and requires monthly payments. These consumer loans can have a high risk of default, and PayPal doesnt own most of themit offloads the U.S. loans to Synchrony Bank. ... Unlike PayPal Credit, PayPal will house these new loans on its own balance sheet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is a big change, especially after they, like, pumped the brakes on lending earlier in the pandemic, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a big change, especially after they, like, pumped the brakes on lending earlier in the pandemic, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This past spring, as the pandemic was spreading quickly and concerns spiked about consumers defaulting on loans, PayPal pumped the brakes on lending. Like many installment lenders, they essentially halted extending loans in March or early April, MoffettNathansons Ellis says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But their senior VP, Doug Bland, says they're "incredibly comfortable in managing the credit risk." So, a renewed, more aggressive push.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But their senior V P, Doug Bland, says they're incredibly comfortable in managing the credit risk. So, a renewed, more aggressive push.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal senior vice president Doug Bland says, We took prudent, responsible action from a risk perspective. With Pay in 4, PayPals renewed push into lending is an indication the company is getting more aggressive in a volatile economy where many consumers have fared better than expected so far. ... Bland says, Were incredibly comfortable in managing the credit risk of this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Fascinating to watch how this plays out in, uh, a changing economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fascinating to watch how this plays out in, uh, a changing economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Big moves in that space.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Big moves in that space.
